title: Part A(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the independent variable in the experiment as the direction the panels face.
The response identifies the independent variable in the experiment as the direction the panels face.

title: Part A(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the dependent variable in the experiment as the amount of electrical energy produced.
The response identifies the dependent variable in the experiment as the amount of electrical energy produced.

title: Part A(iii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify a reasonable hypothesis for the experiment, such as any of the following:

· If the photovoltaic panels face north/south/east/west, then the maximum amount of electricity will be produced.

· The position (compass direction) of solar panels will affect how much energy is produced.

· Solar panels positioned with greatest access to the sun will generate more energy.

· The compass direction the panels face will not have an effect on the amount of electricity produced.

The response identifies a reasonable hypothesis for the experiment, such as one of the following:

· If the photovoltaic panels face north/south/east/west, then the maximum amount of electricity will be produced.

· The position (compass direction) of solar panels will affect how much energy is produced.

· Solar panels positioned with greatest access to the sun will generate more energy.

· The compass direction the panels face will not have an effect on the amount of electricity produced.

title: Part A(iv)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one variable that was not discussed in the study that could affect the results, such as any of the following:

· Panels tilted to an improper angle that does not match the position of the Sun will decrease energy/kWh MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGLbGaaeOBaiaabwgacaqGYbGaae4zaiaabMhacaqGVaGaae4A aiaabEfacaqGObaaaa@3F17@ production.

· Shade or shadows from trees, dust, clouds or snow on the panels would prevent absorption of sunlight, decreasing energy/kWh MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGLbGaaeOBaiaabwgacaqGYbGaae4zaiaabMhacaqGVaGaae4A aiaabEfacaqGObaaaa@3F17@ production.

title: Part B(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the location shown in the diagram where the kinetic energy of the water is transformed into mechanical energy as the turbine.
The response identifies the location shown in the diagram where the kinetic energy of the water is transformed into mechanical energy as the turbine.

title: Part B(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the water in the storage reservoir has potential energy that is useful in hydroelectric power generation, such as any of the following:

· The dam holds water at a higher elevation than the turbine and is allowed to flow downhill toward the turbine.

· Water has potential energy due to gravity allowing water to flow down toward the turbine when released.

· The greater the difference between the dam height (head) and position of the turbine, the more hydrostatic pressure is built up.

The response explains why the water in the storage reservoir has potential energy that is useful in hydroelectric power generation, such as one of the following:

· The dam holds water at a higher elevation than the turbine and is allowed to flow downhill toward the turbine.

· Water has potential energy due to gravity allowing water to flow down toward the turbine when released.

· The greater the difference between the dam height (head) and position of the turbine, the more hydrostatic pressure is built up.

title: Part B(iii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how coupling hydroelectric power with solar or wind power is an advantage to providing a constant source of electricity to a community, such as any of the following:

· Solar and wind power are both intermittent as result of weather changing from day to day (or day to night) so hydroelectric power could be used to provide electricity when the solar or wind power is unavailable/not sufficient for electricity demand.

· Solar or wind power could be used to pump water into a reservoir increasing the amount of water behind the dam to increase hydroelectric power generation.

The response explains how coupling hydroelectric power with solar or wind power is an advantage to providing a constant source of electricity to a community, such as one of the following:

· Solar and wind power are both intermittent as result of weather changing from day to day (or day to night) so hydroelectric power could be used to provide electricity when the solar or wind power is unavailable/not sufficient for electricity demand.

· Solar or wind power could be used to pump water into a reservoir increasing the amount of water behind the dam to increase hydroelectric power generation.

title: Part B(iv)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how a hydroelectric power system, like the one depicted, may be negatively affected by climate change, such as any of the following:

· Decrease in water storage due to drought, evaporation or reduced rain fall decreases the amount of electricity generated.

· Increased need for irrigation due to drought or reduced rainfall leads to reduction of the amount of water stored in reservoirs, decreasing the amount of electricity generated.

· Increased frequency of extreme precipitation events such as floods or droughts as a result of climate change cause a larger amount of sediments to fill the reservoir, reducing storage capacity and decreasing the amount of electricity generated.

· In the short-term, run-off may increase from loss of glaciers, leading to increased water available for power production, increasing the amount of electricity generated.

· In the long-term, after glaciers melt, there will be decreased run-off, decreasing water storage, decreasing the amount of electricity generated.

The response explains how a hydroelectric power system, like the one depicted, may be negatively affected by climate change, such as one of the following:

· Decrease in water storage due to drought, evaporation or reduced rain fall decreases the amount of electricity generated.

· Increased need for irrigation due to drought or reduced rainfall leads to reduction of the amount of water stored in reservoirs, decreasing the amount of electricity generated.

· Increased frequency of extreme precipitation events such as floods or droughts as a result of climate change cause a larger amount of sediments to fill the reservoir, reducing storage capacity and decreasing the amount of electricity generated.

· In the short-term, run-off may increase from loss of glaciers, leading to increased water available for power production, increasing the amount of electricity generated.

· In the long-term, after glaciers melt, there will be decreased run-off, decreasing water storage, decreasing the amount of electricity generated.

title: Part C(i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify one advantage, other than the generation of hydroelectric power, of the formation of a reservoir behind a hydroelectric dam, such as any of the following:

· Increase in aquatic habitat behind the dam/increase in lake species in reservoir

· Provision of recreational facilities

· Increased flood control

· Water storage/drinking water source

· Water for irrigation

The response identifies one advantage, other than the generation of hydroelectric power, of the formation of a reservoir behind a hydroelectric dam, such as one of the following:

· Increase in aquatic habitat behind the dam/increase in lake species in reservoir

· Provision of recreational facilities

· Increased flood control

· Water storage/drinking water source

· Water for irrigation

title: Part C(ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain the effect of increased silt in the reservoir on the hydroelectric power system, such as any of the following:

· Silt in reservoirs decreases water storage capacity and can lead to reduced power generation or reduced potential energy.

· Silt in reservoirs decreases water storage capacity and can lead to the release of water over a spillway, rather than using it to generate electricity.

· Silt can damage the turbine and other mechanical equipment by abrasion of blades. Damaged equipment decreases efficiency and/or requires expensive repairs.

The response explains the effect of increased silt in the reservoir on the hydroelectric power system, such as one of the following:

· Silt in reservoirs decreases water storage capacity and can lead to reduced power generation or reduced potential energy.

· Silt in reservoirs decreases water storage capacity and can lead to the release of water over a spillway, rather than using it to generate electricity.

· Silt can damage the turbine and other mechanical equipment by abrasion of blades. Damaged equipment decreases efficiency and/or requires expensive repairs.
